title.rendered: New Name, Logo, and Identity for Loka Energy by Believe In

content.rendered:
Established in 2014, Loka Energy is — or, more precisely, will be — the energy company responsible for providing low carbon heat into the homes and businesses of the fledgling redevelopment of the Greenwich Peninsula in South East London. Currently home to the O2 Arena and entertainment district, the project will cover a 160-acre site and include 10,000 homes and 3.5 million square feet of commercial space, all of which will rely on a “District Heat Network” (underground pipes, basically) developed and operated by Loka. Its name and identity have been created by Exeter, UK-based Believe In.

The name Loka means ‘local’ in Esperanto, a universal language created to foster harmony between people. It also references low carbon, a key ambition of the network’s approach to energy generation and supply. The bold logotype is formed of geometric shapes inspired by the Greenwich Peninsula identity, and is supported by a range of illustrations by Sodavekt.

Believe In project page

Well, this is different. And unexpected. And possibly a really very ugly thing. I like it! The wordmark is not the most pleasant set of geometric shapes ever assembled but — no pun intended — they have an interesting energy to them that stands apart from any energy company ever, anywhere. It can get away with its eccentricity as Loka will not have a competitor and it will operate in a forward-looking redevelopment project full of fancy and novel things. It’s oddly appropriate and repellingly attractive — as much as I want to hate that stumpy “a” I can’t. The “Energy O” icon, with its warm gradient is a cool device but, compared to the wordmark, it’s not as innovative or engaging.

The other big element of the identity is a set of line-art illustrations by Sodavekt that present a series of heat, energy, and sustainability references as well as an interpretation of the Peninsula, dome and all, in the always pleasant style of monoweight vector lines. It’s not the most novel idea but done so nicely and expertly in this project, it’s hard to argue against it.

The rest of the identity relies heavily on a pink-red-orange gradient and the use of Colophon’s Aperçu type family. In combination with the illustrations, it’s a fun and vibrant set of applications that you will like or hate depending on your opinion of the logo — surely a heated topic in the ensuing comments.
